title-group.article-title: More Human Than Others, but Not Always Better
title-group.subtitle: The Robustness of Self-Humanizing Across Cultures and Interpersonal Comparisons

author-notes.corresp: Joonha Park, Department of Social Psychology, The University of Tokyo, 7-3-1 Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo 113-0033, Japan. Email: jpark35@l.u-tokyo.ac.jp

abstract.p: Research has shown that people perceive themselves as more human than the average person, independent of their tendencies to self-enhance. This self-humanizing (SHN) effect has been examined in comparisons of the self with fictional or average others, but not with actual others such as a real, though unfamiliar, classmate or a friend. In Study 1, European Australian and Japanese undergraduates compared themselves with either an unfamiliar classmate or average university students to examine their tendencies for SHN. SHN was consistently found across the two comparisons and across the two cultures. Study 2 extended the findings by examining self-other comparisons involving close friend or unfamiliar peer among Australian, Japanese, and Korean undergraduates. As predicted, SHN was obtained in every culture, and SHN effect was greater in East Asia than in Australia. In contrast, self-enhancement was weak and inconsistent across samples and comparisons. The findings extend the current theory of SHN, indicating that the effect is robust and present even in comparisons involving individuated actual others.

body.p: People everywhere have understandings of what it means to be human. Those understandings include the properties shared among all humans and essential to human beings (Human Nature) and the properties that distinguish humans from animals (Human Uniqueness; Haslam, Bain, Douge, Lee, & Bastian, 2005). The Human Nature dimension tends to involve warmth (“friendly”), openness (“curious”), and desire and vivacity (“passionate”), whereas Human Uniqueness tends to revolve around refinement (“broad-minded”), civility (“polite”), and rationality (“analytical”; Haslam, Loughnan, Kashima, & Bain, 2008). These understandings of Human Nature and Human Uniqueness appear to have some cross-cultural generality (Park, Haslam, & Kashima, 2012), and the tendency to ascribe more Human Nature traits to the self than to the average person (Haslam et al., 2005), called self-humanizing (SHN), has been observed in Western European based (Australia, Germany, Israel, and the United States) as well as East Asian cultures (Japan, Singapore; Loughnan et al., 2010).

Despite the apparent robustness of SHN across cultures, there are issues related to SHN that deserve greater attention in the literature. A useful point of contrast is provided by the well-known psychological phenomenon of self-enhancement (SE), the tendency to ascribe more desirable traits to the self than to others. Although SE and SHN are biases in self-perception, SHN is distinct from SE because people tend to ascribe Human Nature traits to themselves more than to others regardless of whether those traits are desirable or undesirable (e.g., Haslam et al., 2005). By comparing SHN with SE, we point to areas of further investigation, especially in relation to SHN’s cross-cultural and cross-contextual variability.

First, with regard to cross-cultural variability, an extensive literature on SE bias has resulted in a controversy about whether it is universal, whereas cross-cultural variability in SHN tendencies has not been investigated extensively. Some researchers argue that SE bias is pervasive in individualistic cultures, but not in collectivistic cultures (relativity hypothesis; for example, Heine, 2001), whereas some suggest that it is pan-cultural, although domains and strategies are culture specific (universality hypothesis; for example, Sedikides & Gregg, 2008). Some findings suggest the existence of positive self-regard among collectivists as well as individualists at implicit levels (e.g., Kitayama & Uchida, 2003; Yamaguchi et al., 2007). In contrast, SHN may show more nuanced cross-cultural variability when examined further. In particular, previous research has not found any evidence of SHN with regard to Self-Human Uniqueness (SHU), but it is possible that this effect may be found in some cultures.

Second, in considering cross-contextual variability in self-perception bias, Thomsen, Sidanius, and Fiske (2007) provided a helpful perspective. They argued that SE is inherently relational in that SE biases may vary across types of interpersonal relationships. Indeed, the size of an SE bias is sensitive to the interpersonal relationship between the self and the other person to whom the self is compared (comparison other). First, the SE bias is affected by comparison other individuation. It tends to decrease when the self is compared with individuated others (e.g., a fictional in-group member) rather than generalized others such as the average person (Alicke, Klotz, Breitenbecher, Yurak, & Vredenburg, 1995). Second, the bias seems to be altered by comparison other actualization (i.e., whether the target has an actual relationship with the self). When the self is compared with specific others, whether they are close (e.g., best friends) or unfamiliar (e.g., peers), the SE bias tends to be weakened or reversed (self-effacement). For example, Brown and Kobayashi (2002) found that Japanese participants judged their best friends more favorably than themselves. Americans did not self-enhance relative to their best friends either (see also Endo, Heine, & Lehman, 2000).

In contrast, the effect of comparison other individuation and actualization has not been systematically examined for SHN or SHU across cultures, with almost all studies examining comparisons between the self and the (unindividuated and unactualized) average person (cf. Haslam & Bain, 2007, in Australia). The SHN has never been examined in comparisons of the self with actualized or individuated comparison others across cultures. Inasmuch as comparison others are significant cues for social contexts (i.e., with whom one is interacting), an examination of cross-cultural variability in SHN and SHU is in line with the call for systematic examination of Culture × Context interaction in cross-cultural research (e.g., Kashima, Hardie, Wakimoto, & Kashima, 2011; Leung & Cohen, 2011). Investigating these underresearched self-perception biases across cultures, especially for different comparison others and in contrast to SE, is therefore a priority.

sec.title: Current Studies
sec.p: Two cross-cultural studies examined the SHN and SE biases in comparisons of the self with actual (close or unfamiliar others) or average targets. Study 1 compared the magnitude of SHN and SE between individuated actual (i.e., unfamiliar classmate) and generalized (i.e., university students) comparison others in a Western European based country (Australia) and an East Asian country (Japan). In Study 2, we narrowed our focus on individuated actual comparison others where self is compared with either significant (i.e., close friend) or nonsignificant (i.e., unfamiliar classmate) others and examined SHN, SHU, and SE in Australia, Japan, and Korea.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: Forty-one Australian undergraduates at the University of Melbourne (80% female, M age = 19.63) and 40 Japanese undergraduates at Kyoto University (64.3% female, M age = 19.10) participated in this study. Australian students were recruited by advertisements on a student notice board, and Japanese students were recruited through online advertisement in the university.

sec.title: Materials and Procedures
sec.p: All participants completed a questionnaire. The first two items asked participants to judge the extent to which they possess each of 20 personality traits compared with the comparison other (an unfamiliar classmate or the average university student) on a 7-point scale (1 = much less than him/her, 4 = equivalent, 7 = much more than him/her). The order of these two comparisons was randomized across participants. Next, participants rated the same set of 20 characteristics on two items: Human Nature (“This characteristic is an aspect of ‘human nature’”) and desirability (“This characteristic is desirable. People generally consider this as positive aspect of personality and want to have this characteristic”). The 20 personality characteristics were based on the 10 highest and 10 lowest Human Nature traits for the Australians and Japanese samples in Park et al. (2012). All materials were prepared in English, and translated into Japanese with back-translation procedure by bilinguals.

Both groups completed the questionnaires in small groups in a lab setting under the supervision of the first author. At the end of the study, all participants were debriefed. Participants’ native language was used throughout the experiment. In this study, SE was operationalized as the correlation between self-ratings and social desirability across traits, controlling for the Human Nature ratings of the traits. SHN was operationalized as correlations between self-ratings and Human Nature across traits while controlling for social desirability of the traits.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: First, we present correlations between two types of self-ratings and Human Nature and desirability in each culture in Table 1. Our data consisted of two levels: participants’ repeated ratings (Level 1) nested within the 20 traits (Level 2). Therefore, we conducted a two-level modeling analysis with Hierarchical Linear Modeling (HLM7). We included two effect-coded variables, Culture (Japan = 1; Australia = −1) and Comparison (generalized other = 1; individuated actual = −1), to evaluate whether the effects of SHN and SE differ as a function of compared others, and between cultures.

caption.p: Correlations (SD) Between Self-Ratings, Human Nature and Desirability in Each Country, Study 1.

sec.p: For each analysis, all level-one variables were group mean-centered. The model was significant, t(80) = 116.95, p < .001 (r = 1.00), and more so in Japan than Australia, t(79) = 2.27, p < .05 (r = .25). Table 2 shows the main results. Human Nature and trait desirability (Desirability) were significant predictors of self-ratings, t(79) = 6.42, p < .001, (r = .59) and t(79) = 4.90, p < .001 (r = .48), respectively. The former (SHN) was found to be significantly greater in Japan than in Australia, t(79) = 2.41, p < .05 (r = .26), whereas the latter (SE) was significantly greater in Australia than in Japan, t(79) = −2.48, p < .05 (r = .27). There was a significant interaction between comparison other and desirability, t(79) = 3.27, p < .01 (r = .35), such that SE was significantly greater when the comparison other was a generalized other than when it was an individuated actual other. Furthermore, this two-way interaction was qualified by culture, suggesting that this tendency was present in Australia, but largely absent in Japan, t(79) = −3.13, p < .01 (r = .33). In contrast, the interaction between comparison other and Human Nature was not statistically significant, t(79) = 1.35, p = ns (r = .15). The comparison other main effect and Comparison Other × Culture interaction effects are not meaningfully interpretable in the current context.

caption.p: Unstandardized Coefficients, B (SE), and Effect Sizes, r, of Culture, Human Nature, Desirability, Comparison (Generalized Other = 1; Individuated Actual = −1), and Their Interaction Slopes in the Self-Ratings Model, Study 1.

fn.p: Note: SE = standard error. Interactions between Culture (Australia = −1; Japan = 1) and each slope are presented in odd rows.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The study found consistent SHN across different comparison others and cultures. Consistent with our general hypothesis, participants attributed greater humanness (Human Nature) to themselves regardless of culture (Australian vs. Japanese) or whether comparison other was generalized or individuated/actual, In contrast, SE was stronger when the self was compared with a generalized other (i.e., average university student) than an individuated actual other (i.e., an unfamiliar peer). Moreover, this tendency was present in Australia, but not in Japan. Consistent with the past research, Australians tended to self-enhance more (estimated coefficient for Desirability = .26) than Japanese (estimated coefficient for Desirability = .06; Alicke et al., 1995; Haslam & Bain, 2007) when the comparison other was a generalized other, but there seems less cultural difference for an individuated other (estimated coefficients for desirability = .10 for Australians, and .06 for Japanese). In contrast, there was little cross-cultural or cross-contextual variability for the SHN.

The fact that a cultural difference in SE was greater for a generalized other than an individuated actual other suggests the importance of examining individuated comparisons in self-perception research because it can provide a more nuanced picture of self-perception biases across cultures. In Study 2, we thus attempted to investigate self-perception in comparison with individuated others more fully. In addition, we added another dimension of humanness, Human Uniqueness and another East Asian culture (Korea), and examined SE, SHN, and SHU in Australia, Japan, and Korea.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: Seventy European Australians (61.4% female, M age = 19.64) at the University of Melbourne, Australia; 80 Japanese (43.8% female, M age = 18.86) at Kyoto University, Japan; and 97 Koreans (63.9% female, M age = 20.94) at Chonnam National University, Korea, participated. As in Study 1, Australian students, who were recruited by advertisements on a student notice board, completed the questionnaires in small groups in a lab setting under the supervision of the first author. Japanese and Korean students volunteered to participate in response to verbal invitations from a lecturer and filled out the questionnaires in a lecture setting under supervision of Japanese and Korean research assistants, respectively.

sec.title: Materials and Procedure
sec.p: The basic method was similar to Study 1’s but was more extended in several ways. First, the first two items of the questionnaire asked participants to rate themselves in comparison with a significant other and nonsignificant other. They were first asked to think about (1) a close friend or (2) an unfamiliar classmate, rate the personal significance of the person on a 5-point scale, and then judge the extent to which they possess each of 56 personality traits compared with this person on a 7-point scale (1 = much less than him/her, 4 = equivalent, 7 = much more than him/her). The order of these two comparisons was randomized across participants. Second, Human Nature was assessed with three items: In addition to the direct question about human nature as in Study 1, we included two additional questions asking typicality (“The characteristic is typical and representative of humans”) and early emergence (“The characteristic emerges early in one’s development”). Previous research (e.g., Haslam et al., 2005; Park et al., 2012) showed that the typicality and early emergence are both highly relevant as indicators of the extent to which a characteristic is seen to be part of human nature. Third, we included an item assessing Human Uniqueness (“This characteristic is exclusively or uniquely human; it does not apply to other species”). Finally, we used a larger set of traits. We borrowed Haslam, Bastian, and Bissett’s (2004; Haslam et al., 2005) 80 traits, which covered all domains of the Schwartz Value Survey (Schwartz, 1992) and the Big Five personality factors (Costa & McCrae, 1992) and reduced them to 56 traits that were most easily translated into the two Asian languages; it hence yielded a set that had broad coverage of the major personality dimensions. The traits were half positive and half negative. As in the previous study, all materials were prepared in English, and translated into Japanese and Korean with back-translation procedure by bilinguals. Participants’ native language was used during the experiment.

We operationalized SE as the correlation between self-ratings and social desirability across traits, controlling for Human Nature and Human Uniqueness. SHN was operationalized as correlations between self-ratings and Human Nature across traits while controlling for Human Uniqueness and social desirability of the traits. We also examined SHU with regard to Human Uniqueness by correlations between self-ratings and Human Uniqueness across traits while controlling for Human Nature and social desirability (SHU).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: As in Park et al. (2012), trait ratings for the three Human Nature items showed a congruent unifactorial structure within Australia (73.0% explained variance), Japan (57.5%), and Korea (78.7%) and were combined into a Human Nature index for further analyses. As in Study 1, Table 3 shows correlations between two types of self-ratings and Human Nature, Human Uniqueness and desirability in each culture.

caption.p: Correlations (SD) Between Self-Ratings, Human Nature, Human Uniqueness and Desirability in Each Country, Study 2.

sec.p: The data structure was consistent with that in Study 1 with two levels: Participants’ repeated ratings (Level 1) nested within the 56 traits (Level 2). As in Study 1, the main analyses included effect-coded variables for comparison other (Comparison: close friend = 1; unfamiliar peer = −1) and culture. Because three country samples were examined in this study, we created two effect-coded culture variables: Culture 1 (East Asia vs. Australia: Japan = 1, Korea = 1, Australia = −2) and Culture 2 (Korea vs. Japan: Japan = −1, Korea = 1, Australia = 0). This modeling allowed us to examine whether each of SHN, SHU, and SE differentially occurs as a function of comparison other (i.e., closeness to the self), and whether such effects differ between cultures in two ways (between East Asia and Australia and between Japan and Korea).

As in Study 1, all level-one variables were group mean-centered for each analysis. The model was significant, t(244) = 303.10, p < .001 (r = 1.00) with no significant differences between East Asia and Australia, t(244) = −0.36, p = ns (r = .02), and between Japan and Korea, t(244) = −1.01, p = ns (r = .06). First, Human Nature was significant in predicting self-ratings, t(244) = 9.01, p < .001 (r = . 50). This SHN was significantly greater in East Asia (Japan and Korea) than in Australia, t(244) = 3.14, p < .01 (r = .20), and marginally greater in Korea than in Japan, t(244) = 1.93, p = .06 (r = .12). Second, Human Uniqueness was a significant predictor of self-ratings, t(244) = 6.00, p < .001 (r = .36). The SHU was significantly greater in East Asia than in Australia, t(244) = 0.25, p = .01 (r = .02), and marginally greater in Japan than in Korea, t(244) = −1.67, p = .10 (r = .11). Third, trait desirability (Desirability) was significant in predicting self-ratings, t(244) = 5.08, p < .001 (r = .31). The SE for individuated others was significantly greater in East Asia than in Australia, t(244) = 2.23, p < .05 (r = .14), and greater in Korea than in Japan, t(244) = 5.45, p < .001 (r = .33). Finally, comparison others predicted self-ratings, t(244) = 4.47, p < .001 (r = .28), more in East Asia than Australia, t(244) = 2.07, p < .05 (r = .13), but not different between Japan and Korea, t(244) = −1.51, p = ns (r = .10); however, these effects cannot be meaningfully interpreted in light of the subsequent higher order interaction effects.

For the interactions involving comparison other, we found no significant interactions between comparison other and SHN, t(244) = −0.02, p = ns (r = .001), or SHU, t(244) = −0.92, p = ns (r = .06), across cultures. It implies that the SHN with either HN or HU was relatively consistent regardless of one’s closeness to the comparison other. On the other hand, there was a significant interaction between comparison other and SE, t(244) = −7.41, p < .001 (r = .43), implying that SE was stronger when the self was compared with an unfamiliar peer than with a close friend. The interaction was significantly weaker in Australia than in East Asia, t(244) = −4.35, p < .001 (r = .27). There was no significant difference between Japan and Korea, t(244) = −0.05, p = ns (r = .003). Table 4 summarizes the model predicted by Human Nature, Human Uniqueness, Desirability, and their interactions with Culture and Comparison other.

caption.p: Unstandardized Coefficients, B (SE), and Effect Sizes, r, of Human Nature, Human Uniqueness and desirability Slopes in the Self-Peer and Self-Friend Models in Three Countries, Study 2.

fn.p: Note: SE = standard error. Comparison (close friend = 1; unfamiliar peer = −1) and two cultural variables, Culture 1 (East Asia vs. Australia: Japan = 1, Korea = 1, Australia = −2) and Culture 2 (Japan vs. Korea: Japan = −1, Korea = 1, Australia = 0), were effect-coded.

sec.p: To aid the interpretation of the three-way effects involving culture, we fit the model separately for each self-other comparison in each country: one for self-ratings in comparison with a close friend (self-friend model) and the other for self-ratings in comparison with an unfamiliar peer (self-peer model).
Self-friend/peer model:

All level-one variables were group mean-centered for each analysis. The self-peer models were significant in all countries, Australia, t(244) = 146.41 (r = .99), Japan, t(244) = 144.62 (r = .44), and Korea, t(244) = 139.78 (r = .99), all ps < .001. Likewise, the self-friend models were significant in all countries, Australia, t(244) = 168.60 (r = 1.00), Japan, t(244) = 144.31 (r = .99), and Korea, t(244) = 189.35 (r = 1.00), all ps < .001. Table 5 summarizes both types of models of each country, indicating exact estimates for each slope in each country. In all models, self-ratings were predicted significantly by Human Nature.

caption.p: Unstandardized Coefficients, B (SE), and Effect Sizes, r, of Human Nature, Human Uniqueness and desirability Slopes in the Self-Peer and Self-Friend Models in Three Countries, Study 2.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: We found several similarities and differences in self-perceptions in comparison to different types of individuated actual others across the three countries. First, the SHN was found across cultures and was stronger in East Asia than in Australia. The effect was consistent regardless of whether the self was compared with either a peer or a close friend in every country. We also found a new form of SHN, namely, attribution of greater Human Uniqueness to the self relative to others (SHU). This was again greater in East Asia than in Australia. Importantly, the interactions of either form of SHN with comparison other were not significant, suggesting the robustness of SHN. Finally, SE showed significant variability across cultures and comparison others. Somewhat contrary to the literature, East Asian SE tended to be greater than Australian SE in the present case that involved self comparisons with individuated actual others. As shown in the results of interaction effects, SE was less affected by comparison other in Australia than in East Asia.

In every sample, people self-humanized with regard to Human Nature in comparisons with individuated actual others. Supporting the robustness of SHN, these findings extend previous findings, which had previously demonstrated the SHN effect for comparisons of self to generalized others. The effect was relatively weak in Australia, where past research suggests that target individuation reduces the bias but where target actualization had not previously been used (Haslam & Bain, 2007). According to the current findings, East Asians’ SHN appears to be relatively robust even for close, familiar, and actualized comparison others. SHN may be particularly important in East Asian cultures for reasons as yet unknown.

East Asians, compared with Australians, also showed a significant tendency to attribute greater Human Uniqueness to the self than to others (SHU). Although uniquely human emotions have been examined extensively in intergroup perceptions (Leyens et al., 2000), Human Uniqueness has not been the primary focus of SHN research. Although the SHU effect does not appear to be as strong as the SHN, the current findings suggest the existence of this tendency especially in East Asian cultures.

The SE bias was stronger in the East Asian samples than the Australian sample. Significant interaction effects with comparison others imply that the bias was influenced by participants’ closeness to the others in Japan or Korea more than in Australia. Basically, East Asians self-enhance when they compare themselves to unfamiliar others than to a close friend. More specifically, a separate modeling by country in preliminary analysis (see Table 5) implied that Japanese do not self-enhance to close friends, but self-efface, consistent with previous research (Brown & Kobayashi, 2002). In contrast, Australians’ SE bias was relatively weak in the present context of comparing the self to individuated others, and it seems to be most apparent when they compare themselves to de-individuated, generalized comparison others as in Study 1. This is indeed understood to be a general characteristic of self-serving bias in the literature (Alicke et al., 1995). In summary, we found the SHN bias to be relatively robust across different comparisons of self with actual individuals and across different countries, as well as some novel and unexpected findings for the SHU and SE effects.

sec.title: General Discussion
sec.p: Our findings show a clear difference between the SE and SHN effects. This difference is consistent with findings reported by Loughnan et al. (2010), and goes beyond their results. The SHN effect was relatively consistent across cultures and comparison others varying in individuation and actualization (Study 1) and closeness while holding individuation/actualization constant (Study 2). The effect appeared robustly even in comparisons between the self and close others, the first time this finding has been obtained. In contrast, the SE bias varied substantially across comparison others and cultures, reversing in some cases, disappearing in others, and differing between East Asian and Australian samples in varying ways.

The SE findings challenge the common assumption that Westerners routinely self-enhance more than non-Westerners. This assumption may less likely hold when people compare themselves to actual concrete individuals. In Study 2, SE significantly interacted with comparison others less in Australia than East Asia. Surprisingly, although SE is usually difficult to find in East Asians’ comparisons of self with generalized abstract others (Heine, 2001), we found it reliably in their comparisons of the self with unfamiliar individuated actual others. This appears to be a pattern opposite to the one found for the Australian participants, for whom SE is often easy to find in the self-generalized other comparison (see Study 1) but was absent in the latter comparisons (see Study 2). These findings suggest that, in SE research, target individuation and actualization may have different implications in different cultures.

It is also interesting to look at the difference between Japanese and Korean participants’ SE in Study 2. Koreans self-enhanced in comparisons with close friends as well as unfamiliar peers, whereas Japanese self-enhanced relative to unfamiliar peers but self-effaced relative to close friends. The findings give mixed support to the universality and relativity hypotheses. Partly consistent with the universality view, East Asians did self-enhance (especially relative to unfamiliar peers). On the other hand, Japanese self-effaced in relation to close friends supports the relativity hypothesis. The Japanese finding is consistent with Brown and Kobayashi (2002), who reported that Japanese, unlike European Americans and Asian Americans, rated their best friends more positively than themselves. On the other hand, Koreans showed significant SE relative to close others as well as to unfamiliar others in our study. In a broader sense though, East Asians’ self-perceptions may be less homogeneous than often assumed. This argument is consistent with Yamaguchi et al. (2007), who found that explicit SE was lower for Japanese than for Chinese participants.

Taken together, the current findings seem to call for an adjustment to the common view of SE and culture (Heine, 2001; Markus & Kitayama, 1991). Although SE was not our primary focus in this article, there seems to be a need to reconceptualize this bias given that it was observed to be relatively high for East Asian participants in certain comparisons (i.e., with actual individuals). Perhaps, independence and interdependence by itself cannot explain the variability in SE within and across cultures, but there may be other societal factors which can complement the current understanding (e.g., “inequality”: Loughnan et al., 2011; Thomsen et al., 2007; “vertical individualism”: Triandis & Gelfand, 1998). Future research may shed light on this by conducting more nuanced investigations of cultural differences, by comparing North America and Australia, as well as by comparing Japan and Korea, while examining patterns of SE for different targets. Leung and Cohen’s (2011) Culture, Personality, and Situation (CuPS) approach is a good example which considers cultural differences among three distinct cultures of dignity, honor, and face and individual variances within each culture.

We believe that more nuanced cross-cultural investigations should be particularly necessary in East Asia. Although a few studies suggest that East Asian cultures differ from each other in subtle ways (e.g., Kashima et al., 1995; Yamaguchi et al., 2007), systematic explanations for such differences are yet lacking. Promisingly, Kashima, Koval, and Kashima’s (2011) recent analysis of culture and self considers cultural change and history as a potential factor for explaining cultural differences between Japan and other Asian countries.

Across samples and comparison types in this study, SHN was observed consistently, whereas SE showed more variability depending on comparison other individuation or closeness as well as cultures. These findings imply that SHN is a more robust phenomenon across target variations (on concreteness and closeness) and cultures than SE. In short, people tend to regard themselves as more human than a wide variety of target others (close or unfamiliar, individuated or generalized), whereas their perceptions of their relative desirability (i.e., SE) fluctuate depending on the nature of the comparison target (Kitayama & Uchida, 2003).

The apparent robustness of the SHN implies that attributing humanness to the self is a fundamental phenomenon that may occur universally. Although tentative, we suspect that this phenomenon may be connected with the inherent motivation for positive self-regard. Although humanness encompasses desirable and undesirable characteristics, individuals’ implicit attitudes toward what it means to be human may be positive (Haslam et al., 2004). Even if some people show modesty at an explicit level (e.g., self-effacement), they may retain a subtle bias that elevates them on the humanness dimension. Our finding in Japan in Study 2 is a good example, in that participants appeared to think that “My friend is better than me, but I am more human than him/her.” It is a question for future research whether SHN is related to the apparently universal tendency for implicit positive self-regard (Kitayama & Uchida, 2003; Yamaguchi et al., 2007).

Our work also provides evidence of a SHU effect, namely, a tendency to attribute uniquely human traits to themselves more than to others. This is a new form of SHN that was observed in all cultural groups though more strongly among East Asians than Australians. The present findings call for a further investigation in self-humanization with regard to Human Uniqueness. In addition, this sense of humanness may be especially salient in East Asian cultural contexts, and may thus be a relatively accessible dimension of social perception and comparison (Bain, Park, Kwok, & Haslam, 2009).

In conclusion, this study found that SHN is a robust effect that occurs across three disparate cultures, even when the self is compared with actual individuals, including close friends. It was primarily found in the attribution of Human Nature to the self (SHN), but also, especially in the East Asian samples, in the attribution of Human Uniqueness (SHU). In contrast, SE, the attribution of desirable traits to the self more than to others, was weaker than SHN in comparisons with individuated actual others, and was inconsistent across cultures and comparison others. These findings refine and extend the current picture of how people from different cultures perceive the self.

fn.p: The author(s) received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

ref.citation: AlickeM. D. KlotzM. L. BreitenbecherD. L. YurakT. J. VredenburgD. S. (1995). Personal contact, individuation, and the better than-average effect. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 68, 804-825.
BainP. ParkJ. KwokC. HaslamN. (2009). Attributing human uniqueness and human nature to cultural groups: Distinct forms of subtle dehumanization. Group Processes & Intergroup Relations, 12, 789-805.
BrownJ. KobayashiC. (2002). Self-enhancement in Japan and America. Asian Journal of Social Psychology, 5, 145-168.
CostaP. T. McCraeR. R. (1992). NEO-PI-R professional manual. Odessa, FL: Psychological Assessment Resources.
EndoY. HeineS. J. LehmanD. R. (2000). Culture and positive illusions in close relationships: How my relationships are better than yours. Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin, 26, 1571-1586.
HaslamN. BainP. (2007). Humanizing the self: Moderators of the attribution of lesser humanness to others. Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin, 33, 57-68.
HaslamN. BainP. DougeL. LeeM. BastianB. (2005). More human than you: Attributing humanness to self and others. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 89, 937-950.
